ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I had taken four years of Spanish previously, so most of the content in the course was review for me, but since I hadn't taken spanish senior year, that was helpful. In general, Professor Baffi is a wonderful, kind teacher, and the course mainly was challenging because it was online. However, I think I developed and reviewed grammar a lot and conjugations.
I became a lot more fluent in conversational Spanish.
Significantly improved all aspects of my Spanish, especially my ability to speak it.
This Spanish course has a large emphasis on grammar and writing skills. I am a much better writer in Spanish after this class.
Developed speaking/listening/reading/writing skills, learned new verb tenses and vocabulary, learned about culture of different Spanish-speaking countries

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The main weakness was that our class was not into participating or vibing very much, but Professor Baffi was so kind and patient and willing to give extensions. The general course material felt like a lot at times and was more heavy grammar/vocab/conjugation than speaking. I feel like the class might not feel as rewarding as learning a new language if you've done spanish in high school, but as long as you don't get too behind, it's not overwhelming.

Strengths: I think the synchronous and asynchronous lectures were a lot more valuable than just completely synchronous. 
Weaknesses: The amount of work done outside class feels excessive sometimes.

This class has a fair amount of reading, which is helpful for me to understand how vocabs are used in real-life content and to develop my own writing style.
However, this class has a relatively light emphasis on listening.

This course is very rigorous and I learned a large amount of material in a short period of time. I wish we had more time to practice speaking as we learned new verb tenses; we tended to do extensive reading/writing assignments when we learned new verb tenses but did not practice integrating them while speaking. I also wish we had more project-based assignments and presentations because the worksheets and types of assignments were somewhat repetitive. Professor Baffi had us do an assignment where we created a magazine cover and did extensive research on an environmental issue of our choice. That was one of my favorite assignments of the semester- it would have been nice to do more projects like that one.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I kind of gave up on asynchronous work, so I had to catch up before exams kind of quickly. It's also kinda annoying that all 130 kids gotta do the same stuff in exams cuz baffi didn't plan it, but baffi was nice and tried making stuff work better for us. when we were in good breakout rooms, it was a little better. baffi was also always willing to help through office hours or email.

The asynchronous work was a really big help! However, I do think the amount of work assigned outside class could have been dialed down a bit, perhaps just to SuperSite and the readings we needed to do.

My professor used breakout rooms a lot to ensure that we were getting enough time to converse with our classmates and develop our speaking skills, which I really appreciated. The synchronous/asynchronous format was good, but I feel that having class every day would have been more beneficial because it would have given us more opportunities to converse with each other.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: if you want to learn spanish or to knock out some language recs then take it, though if your high school was bad at spanish, you will have to work harder. prof baffi is so kind and sweet though so try to get in her section
Yes, a great class to work on your Spanish while working with cultural material.

This course is an intense, rigorous language class that requires a lot of effort. The department gives you all the tools to succeed and develop your Spanish skills, but your growth ultimately depends on how much effort you put into it. I would recommend this class for anyone who is seeking to advance their Spanish grammar skills and learn about Spanish/Latin American culture.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
